title: Meissen porcelain
text:
Meissen porcelain or Meissen china was the first European <a href="hard-paste%20porcelain">hard-paste porcelain</a>. Early experiments were done in 1708 by <a href="Ehrenfried%20Walther%20von%20Tschirnhaus">Ehrenfried Walther von Tschirnhaus</a>. After his death that October, <a href="Johann%20Friedrich%20B%C3%B6ttger">Johann Friedrich Böttger</a> continued von Tschirnhaus's work and brought this type of porcelain to the market, financed by <a href="King%20Augustus%20II%20of%20Poland">Augustus the Strong, King of Poland and Elector of Saxony</a>. The production of porcelain in the royal factory at <a href="Meissen">Meissen</a>, near <a href="Dresden">Dresden</a>, started in 1710 and attracted artists and artisans to establish, arguably, the most famous porcelain manufacturer known throughout the world. Its signature <a href="logo">logo</a>, the crossed swords, was introduced in 1720 to protect its production; the mark of the swords is reportedly one of the oldest <a href="trademark">trademark</a>s in existence. "Dresden porcelain" was once the usual term for these wares, until the (Higher Munich State Court) decided in favour of the Saxon Porcelain Manufactory Dresden, which alone was then allowed to use the name "<a href="Dresden%20Porcelain">Dresden Porcelain</a>".
Meissen remained the dominant European porcelain factory, and the leader of stylistic innovation, until somewhat overtaken by the new styles introduced by the French <a href="Manufacture%20nationale%20de%20S%C3%A8vres">Sèvres factory</a> in the 1760s, but has remained a leading factory to the present day. Among the developments pioneered by Meissen are the porcelain figurines, and the introduction of European decorative styles to replace the imitation of Asian decoration of its earliest wares.
Since 1991, the manufactory has been operating as the , whose owner is the <a href="Free%20State%20of%20Saxony">Free State of Saxony</a>. The company is one of the world's leading porcelain manufacturers and one of the oldest and most internationally known German luxury brands.
Beginnings.
<a href="Chinese%20porcelain">Chinese porcelain</a> had gradually developed over centuries, and by the seventeenth century both <a href="Chinese%20export%20porcelain">Chinese</a> and <a href="Japanese%20export%20porcelain">Japanese export porcelain</a> were imported to Europe on a large scale by the <a href="Dutch%20East%20India%20Company">Dutch East India Company</a> and its equivalents in other countries. It was a very expensive product by the time it reached European customers, and represented wealth, importance and refined taste in Europe. European attempts to produce porcelain, such as the brief experiment that produced <a href="Medici%20porcelain">Medici porcelain</a> in <a href="Florence">Florence</a>, had met with failure.
At the beginning of the eighteenth century Johann Friedrich Böttger pretended he had solved the dream of the <a href="Alchemy">alchemist</a>s, to produce gold from worthless materials. When <a href="King%20Augustus%20II%20of%20Poland">King Augustus II of Poland</a> heard of it, he kept him in protective custody and requested him to produce gold. For years Johann Friedrich Böttger was unsuccessful in this effort.
At the same time, <a href="Ehrenfried%20Walther%20von%20Tschirnhaus">Ehrenfried Walther von Tschirnhaus</a>, a mathematician and scientist, experimented with the manufacture of glass, trying to make porcelain as well. Crucially, his ingredients included <a href="kaolin">kaolin</a>, the vital ingredient of true porcelain, though he was unable to use it successfully. Tschirnhaus supervised Böttger and by 1707 Böttger reluctantly started to help in the experiments by Tschirnhaus.
When Tschirnhaus suddenly died, the recipe apparently was handed over to Böttger, who within one week announced to the King that he could make porcelain. Böttger refined the formula and with some Dutch co-workers, experienced in firing and painting <a href="tiles">tiles</a>, the stage was set for the manufacturing of porcelain. In 1709, the King established the "Royal-Polish and Electoral-Saxon Porcelain Manufactory" ("Königlich-Polnische und Kurfürstlich-Sächsische Porzellan-Manufaktur"), placed Böttger's laboratory at <a href="Albrechtsburg">Albrechtsburg</a> castle in <a href="Meissen">Meissen</a> and production started officially in 1710.
Early work.
The first type of ware produced by Böttger was a refined and extremely hard red <a href="stoneware">stoneware</a> known as "Böttger ware" in English (in ). This copied Chinese <a href="Yixing%20ware">Yixing ware</a>, and like that was especially used for teapots, and now coffee pots. Similar wares had been made by the Dutch and the <a href="Elers%20brothers">Elers brothers</a> in England. Böttger's version was harder than any of these, and retained very crisp definition in its cast or applied (<a href="Sprigging">"sprigged"</a>) details, on bodies that could be polished to a gloss before firing. Models were derived from <a href="Baroque">Baroque</a> silver shapes and Chinese ceramic examples. There was also a softer stoneware, which was glazed and decorated. Meissen's production of a <a href="Hard-paste%20porcelain">hard paste white porcelain</a> that could be glazed and painted soon followed, and wares were put on the market in 1713.
Böttger's experimental wares rapidly gained quality but never achieved successful painted and fired decor. The first successful ornaments were gold decorations applied upon the fired body and finely engraved before they received a second firing at a lower temperature. The lacy frameworks outside painted scenes known in German as in red, gold or <a href="puce">puce</a>, were often used. Augustus II charged first Johann Jakob Irminger with the design of new vessels. In 1720 <a href="Johann%20Gregor%20Herold">Johann Gregor Herold</a> became the director and in 1723 introduced brilliant <a href="overglaze">overglaze</a> colours that made Meissen porcelain famous, with an increasingly broad palette of colors that marked the beginning of the classic phase of Meissen porcelain. His enamel paints are still the basis for ceramic paints today. Initially painting mostly imitated the oriental designs known from <a href="Chinese%20export%20porcelain">Chinese</a> and <a href="Japanese%20export%20porcelain">Japanese export porcelain</a>, but some European landscape scenes were painted from early on.
The signature <a href="underglaze">underglaze</a> "Meissen Blue" was introduced by Friedrich August Köttig. Soon minutely detailed landscapes and port scenes, animals, flowers, "galante" courtly scenes and "<a href="chinoiserie">chinoiserie</a>s", fanciful Chinese-inspired decorations, were to be found on Meissen porcelain. The "<a href="Kakiemon">Kakiemon</a>" floral decoration of vases and <a href="tea%20ware">tea ware</a>s in <a href="Japanese%20export%20porcelain">Japanese export porcelain</a> were combined with Chinese <a href="famille%20verte">famille verte</a> to create a style known as ("Indian Flowers"); Augustus had large collections of both Chinese and Japanese porcelain. Coloured grounds with decoration painted on white in panels appear in the 1730s. Paintings by <a href="Watteau">Watteau</a> were copied. Wares were also sold with plain glazed colors, usually white, to be enamelled in private workshops (), many in <a href="Augsburg">Augsburg</a> and <a href="Bayreuth">Bayreuth</a>, and independently retailed. The support of Augustus' patronage attracted to Meissen some of the finest painters and modellers of Europe as staff artists.
Famous trademark.
The Albrechtsburg was utilized to protect the secrets of the manufacture of the white gold. As a further precaution, very few workers knew the <a href="wikt%3Aarcanum">"arcanum"</a> (hidden, secret knowledge) of how to make porcelain, and then perhaps only part of the process. Thus, for a few years, Meissen retained its monopoly on the production of hard-paste porcelain in Europe. By 1717, however, a competing production was set up at Vienna, as Samuel Stöltzel, head of the craftsmen and arcanist at Meissen, sold the secret recipe, which involved the use of <a href="kaolin">kaolin</a>, also known as china clay. By 1760 about thirty porcelain manufacturers were operating in Europe, most of them, however, producing <a href="frit">frit</a> based <a href="soft-paste%20porcelain">soft-paste porcelain</a>.
In order to identify the original Meissen products, Meissen developed markings that initially were painted on, but were soon fired in underglaze blue. Early markings such as "AR" (Augustus Rex, the monogram of the King), "K.P.M." (), "M.P.M." (), and "K.P.F." () were eventually replaced by the crossed swords logo, based on the arms of the <a href="Elector%20of%20Saxony">Elector of Saxony</a> as <a href="Arch-Marshal">Arch-Marshal</a> of the <a href="Holy%20Roman%20Empire">Holy Roman Empire</a>. Introduced in 1720, the logo was used consistently after 1731 by official decree. Variations in the logo allow approximate dating of the wares. However, in the 18th century, the mark was not considered important, and it was commonly painted on in a crude manner. It wasn't until the "dot period" when a gentleman asked that the mark be adjusted to look older that the factory got serious about mark control.
Artistic development.
After Irminger, the next chief modeller, Johann Jakob Kirchner, was the first to make large-scale statues and figurines, especially of Baroque saints. His assistant was <a href="Johann%20Joachim%20Kaendler">Johann Joachim Kaendler</a>; in 1733 Kirchner resigned, and Kaendler took over as chief modeller, remaining in place until his death in 1775, and becoming the most famous of the Meissen modellers. Under his direction Meissen produced the series of small figurines, which brought out the best of the new material (see below). His menagerie of large-scale animals, left in the white, are some of the high points of European porcelain manufacture. His work resulted in the production of exquisite figurines in the <a href="rococo">rococo</a> style that influenced porcelain making in all of Europe. He was supported by assistants like Johann Friedrich Eberlein and Peter Reinecke.
In 1756, during the <a href="Seven%20Years%27%20War">Seven Years' War</a>, Prussian troops occupied Meissen, giving <a href="Frederick%20II%20of%20Prussia">Frederick II of Prussia</a> the opportunity to relocate some of the artisans to establish the <a href="Royal%20Porcelain%20Manufacture%20Berlin">Royal Porcelain Manufacture Berlin</a> (; KPMB). With the changing tastes of the neoclassical period and the rise of <a href="S%C3%A8vres%20porcelain">Sèvres porcelain</a> in the 1760s, Meissen had to readjust its production, and in the reorganization from 1763, C.W.E. Dietrich of the Dresden Academy became artistic director and Michel-Victor Acier from France became the modelmaster. The practice of impressing numerals that correspond to moulds in the inventory books began in 1763.
Marcolini period.
Sèvres styles and ventures into <a href="Neoclassicism">Neoclassicism</a>, such as unglazed matte <a href="biscuit%20porcelain">biscuit porcelain</a> wares that had the effect of white marble, marked the manufactory's output under <a href="Count%20Camillo%20Marcolini">Count Camillo Marcolini</a>, who ran the factory from 1774 to 1813, when after the <a href="Battle%20of%20Leipzig">Battle of Leipzig</a> he followed <a href="Frederick%20Augustus%20I%20of%20Saxony">Frederick Augustus I of Saxony</a> into exile, dying in <a href="Prague">Prague</a> the next year. Meissen wares were slightly reduced in quality, and considerably in quantity during this period, as both <a href="Austria">Austria</a> and <a href="Prussia">Prussia</a> banned imports, and Britain, France and Russia placed high <a href="tariff">tariff</a>s on imports - all now had their own industries to protect.
19th-century.
In the nineteenth century Ernst August Leuteritz modernized many of the rococo figurines, and reissued them, creating a "Second Rococo" characterized by lacework details (made from actual lace dipped in slip and fired) and applied flowers. After about 1830 the fortunes of the factory revived, although with wares that appeal less to modern taste than the 18th-century ones. The factory had great commercial success with the <a href="lithophane">lithophane</a> technique, introduced in 1829, which produced a picture when held up to the light.
20th-century.
Under Erich Hösel, who became head of the modelling department in 1903, old styles were revived and reinterpreted. Hösel also restored eighteenth century models. Some appealing work in the <a href="Art%20Nouveau">Art Nouveau</a> style was produced, but Meissen's mainstay continued to be the constant production of revived eighteenth-century models.
After 1933, the artistic freedom of the artists became restricted by the State of Saxony in accordance with the contemporary indoctrination process in Germany. Some artists (i.e. <a href="Ernst%20Barlach">Ernst Barlach</a>) who had contributed to progressive Meissen during the Weimar period were banned.
After World War II and under Communist rule, the manufactory that had always catered to the rich and wealthy had some difficulty to find its way. The danger was that Meissen would become a factory merely producing for the masses. It was not until 1969, when Karl Petermann became the director, that Meissen went back to focus on its old traditions and was also allowed a freer artistic expression.
Figures.
Figurines had been produced under Böttger, when a small white figure of <a href="Augustus%20II%20the%20Strong">Augustus II the Strong</a> was produced. <a href="Johann%20Joachim%20K%C3%A4ndler">Johann Joachim Kändler</a> modelled many of the most famous figures, which were initially made for decorating the tables at grand meals, usually in white, replacing <a href="sugar%20sculpture">sugar sculpture</a>s. However, they soon became very popular as ornaments for living rooms and were cheaper than an entire table service, so available to a rather wider market, both in terms of geography and social class. Kändler soon had them brightly painted, increasing their attraction.
Human figures were mostly courtiers, shepherds and shepherdesses (Dresden shepherdess is a proverbial term), characters, animals, <a href="personification">personification</a>s or "allegorical figures" (such the seasons, virtues, or <a href="Four%20continents">continents</a>) and figures in Chinese and Turkish costumes. As well as the pastoral fantasy shepherdesses there were also some more realistic figures of urban workers, based on print series of the <a href="street%20cries">street cries</a> of Paris, London and other cities. In the 1750s a large series of miners was produced. The Meissen repertoire had a huge influence on other European porcelain factories, and the porcelain figure is a defining object for the <a href="Rococo">Rococo</a>.
Kändler also produced a <a href="modello">modello</a> of <a href="Augustus%20III%20of%20Poland">Augustus III of Poland</a> on a horse which was intended to be a life size statue for the city. There is an all white figure of the "Triumph of Amphitrite" in Berlin that is the only known figure signed by Kändler.
A famous large group, or <a href="menagerie">menagerie</a>, of animal figures were ordered by Augustus for the <a href="Japanese%20Palace">Japanese Palace</a> he was building in the 1720s. Kändler took the series over in 1733, and modelled most of the figures. These were often many times the size of most figures, and making them posed great technical problems. Nonetheless, when seen as a group they were a sight that astonished and impressed visitors. Smaller figures of animals, especially birds, were also very popular.
The "Monkey Band" (, ), are a comic group of figures of monkey musicians, and a larger excited conductor, all in fancy contemporary costumes. They were first modelled by Kändler and Reinicke in 1753-54, with a later set in the 1760s. They were copied by <a href="Chelsea%20porcelain">Chelsea porcelain</a> and others. Such <a href="singerie">singerie</a> were popular in various media.
Tableware patterns.
Böttger early foresaw the production of <a href="tableware">tableware</a>, and the first services were made in the 1720s. Initial services were plain, but Kaendler soon introduced matching decorations. Kaendler also produced the 1745 "New Cutout" pattern, characterized by a wavy edge cut, and is presumed to have designed the much-copied <a href="osier%20pattern">osier pattern</a> of a <a href="relief">relief</a> border imitating a woven <a href="wicker">wicker</a> or <a href="Common%20osier">osier</a> fence.
Initially relatively small tea and coffee services were the most produced, but from the 1730s large <a href="armorial%20porcelain">armorial porcelain</a> dinner services began to be made, initially for Augustus, but then other buyers in Germany and abroad. They also became used for diplomatic gifts. <a href="Maria%20Amalia%20of%20Saxony">Maria Amalia of Saxony</a>, granddaughter of Augustus, married the King of the Three Sicilies, later <a href="Charles%20III%20of%20Spain">Charles III of Spain</a>, and her dowry is said to have included 17 Meissen table services, inspiring the couple to found the <a href="Capodimonte%20porcelain">Capodimonte porcelain</a> factoruy in <a href="Naples">Naples</a>.
The most famous of these is the <a href="Swan%20Service">Swan Service</a> () made in 1737-1743, for the manufactory's director, Count <a href="Heinrich%20von%20Br%C3%BChl">Heinrich von Brühl</a>; It eventually numbered more than a thousand pieces. At the end of World War II, the pieces of the Swan Service were scattered amongst collectors and museums. Yet, with the moulds still available, the pattern continues to be made today. The <a href="M%C3%B6llendorff%20Dinner%20Service">Möllendorff Dinner Service</a> of the 1760s is another huge service, also today divided between many collections.
The <a href="Blue%20Onion">Blue Onion</a> pattern (in fact copying Chinese <a href="pomegranate">pomegranate</a>s) has been in production for close to three centuries. It was effectively designed by Höroldt in 1739 and is probably inspired by a Chinese bowl from the <a href="Kangxi%20Emperor">Kangxi period</a>. Widely popular, the pattern has been copied extensively by over sixty companies; some of those competitors have even used the word "Meissen" as a marking. But the pattern became so popular and widespread that the German Supreme Court in 1926 ruled that the "Meissen Zwiebelmuster" was in the public domain.
A series of "Court Dragon" and "Red Dragon" tableware patterns features Chinese dragons, generally in underglaze red with gilt details flying around the rim of the plate and with a medallion in the center of the <a href="Cavetto%23Vessels">cavetto</a>. A version of this pattern was used in Hitler's "<a href="Kehlsteinhaus">Kehlsteinhaus</a>" retreat.
Other popular patterns still in production include the "Purple Rose" pattern and the "Vine-leaf" pattern.
Ownership.
At the beginning the Meissen manufactory was owned by the King of <a href="Saxony">Saxony</a>; by 1830 it came to belong to the State of Saxony. After World War II, most of the equipment was sent to the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a> as part of <a href="war%20reparations">war reparations</a>. However, already by 1946, the workers using traditional methods and the <a href="kiln">kiln</a>s that had not been dismantled were able to resume production. The company became a Soviet Joint Stock Company in Germany. Almost all of the production was sent to the Soviet Union, a crucial step that kept the artisan community alive. After the establishment of the <a href="German%20Democratic%20Republic">German Democratic Republic</a>, the company was handed over to German ownership in 1950 and became a (VEB), a "people-owned company". turned out to be one of the few profitable companies in the economically troubled East German system, earning much needed foreign currency. After the German reunification in 1990, the company was restored to the <a href="States%20of%20Germany">State</a> of <a href="Saxony">Saxony</a> which is the sole owner. While its products are expensive, the high quality and artistic value make Meissen porcelain desirable by collectors and connoisseurs.
Meissen collections.
The rarity and expense of Meissen porcelain meant that originally it could be bought only by the upper classes; this gradually changed over the 19th century. When a wealthy class emerged in the United States in the nineteenth century, such families as the <a href="Vanderbilt%20family">Vanderbilts</a> started their own collections. Many of these collections then found their way into the world's great museums, including the <a href="Dixon%20Gallery%20and%20Gardens">Dixon Gallery and Gardens</a>, featuring one of the largest collections in America.
A collection of 117 chinoiserie items, including a mantel clock case made for Augustus the Strong dated 1727, which had been assembled by Dr <a href="Franz%20Oppenheimer%20%28art%20collector%29">Franz Oppenheimer</a> and his wife, Margarethe, was auctioned by <a href="Sotheby%27s">Sotheby's</a> in September 2021.
A Meissen porcelain chocolate pot, cover, and stand, dated c.1780, were amongst the wedding gifts of <a href="Queen%20Elizabeth%20II">Queen Elizabeth II</a>.
